qas.question: During what century did the Investiture Controversy occur?
When did the reign of Pope Leo IX begin?
What pope was involved in the Investiture Controversy?
In what year was the Concordat of Worms agreed to?
What secular rulers did the Concordat of Worms increase the power of?

context: Monastic reform inspired change in the secular church. The ideals that it was based upon were brought to the papacy by Pope Leo IX (pope <a1_0>1049<a1_0/>–1054), and provided the ideology of the clerical independence that led to the Investiture Controversy in the late <a0_0>11th<a0_0/> century. This involved <a2_0>Pope Gregory VII<a2_0/> (pope 1073–85) and Emperor Henry IV, who initially clashed over episcopal appointments, a dispute that turned into a battle over the ideas of investiture, clerical marriage, and simony. The emperor saw the protection of the Church as one of his responsibilities as well as wanting to preserve the right to appoint his own choices as bishops within his lands, but the papacy insisted on the Church's independence from secular lords. These issues remained unresolved after the compromise of <a3_0>1122<a3_0/> known as the Concordat of Worms. The dispute represents a significant stage in the creation of a papal monarchy separate from and equal to lay authorities. It also had the permanent consequence of empowering <a4_0>German princes<a4_0/> at the expense of the German emperors.
